{{italic title}} '''''The Dance II''''' by [[Henri Matisse]] is a [[triptych]] [[mural]] (15 ft high by 45 ft long) in the [[Barnes Foundation]]. It was created in 1932<ref>[http://www.artfagcity.com/2012/05/16/whats-so-special-about-the-barnes-collection/ ''New Barnes Building Opens, Why People are Upset'']</ref> at the request of [[Albert C. Barnes]] after he met Matisse in the United States. Barnes was an art enthusiast and long-time collector of Matisse's works, and agreed to pay Matisse a total of $30,000 for the mural, which was expected to take a year.<ref name=flam>Flam, Jack, ''Matisse: The Dance'', National Gallery of Art, Washington, 1993.</ref>
The mural was to be placed above three arches spanning the windows of the main hall of Barnes' gallery. In Nice, France, Matisse executed the mural on canvas provided by Barnes, as opposed to working on site. This was an unusual approach for such a work, but the patron had offered him complete artistic freedom, and working onsite would in any event have been impractical.
For Matisse, the project proved to be beset with difficulties, and would end up taking him two years, leaving him physically and emotionally drained. He was also profoundly disappointed to be told on installation that Barnes had no intention of exhibiting the work to the public.<ref>Spurling, Hilary, ''Matisse the Master'', Penguin Books, London, 2006 at 337</ref>
Nevertheless, Matisse was delighted with the work itself. In a 1933 letter to his son, Matisse wrote about the installation at the Barnes Foundation: "It has a splendour that one can't imagine unless one sees it -- because both the whole ceiling and its arched vaults come alive through radiation and the main effect continues right down to the floor...I am profoundly tired but very pleased. When I saw the canvas put in place, it was detached from me and became part of the building."<ref name=flam/>
Some commentators consider that ''The Dance II'' mural was pivotal in enabling Matisse to return to the most essential sources of his art.<ref name=flam/><ref>Bois, Y-A, “The Shift”, in Turner and Benjamin, eds, Matisse, Brisbane: QAG 1995 at 98</ref> For Matisse, the work highlighted aspects such as simplicity, flattening, the emphasis on colour and the use of paper cut-outs which would all go on to play an important role in his later artistic development.<ref>"Strange encounters", in www.artinsociety.com</ref>
==Damage during world tour== During a 1993 hearing in the Montgomery County, Pennsylvania Orphan's Court art conservator Paul R. Himmelstein argued that ''The Dance II'' suffered significant damages during a controversial world tour of highlights from the Barnes Foundation's collection of Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings.<ref>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=John|title=Art Held Hostage: The Battle Over the Barnes Collection|pages=107}}</ref>

{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = The Fault in Our Stars | image = The Fault in Our Stars (Official Film Poster).png | alt = Movie poster featuring Shailene Woodley and Ansel Elgort in character | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Josh Boone (director)|Josh Boone]] | producer = {{plainlist| * [[Wyck Godfrey]] * Marty Bowen }} | screenplay = {{plainlist| * [[Scott Neustadter]] * [[Michael H. Weber]] }} | based on = {{based on|''[[The Fault in Our Stars]]''|[[John Green (author)|John Green]]}} | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Shailene Woodley]] * [[Ansel Elgort]] * [[Laura Dern]] * [[Sam Trammell]] * [[Nat Wolff]] * [[Willem Dafoe]] }} | music = {{plainlist| * [[Mike Mogis]] * [[Nate Walcott]] }} | cinematography = [[Ben Richardson]] | editing = Robb Sullivan | studio = {{plainlist| * [[Fox 2000 Pictures]] * [[Temple Hill Entertainment]] * [[TSG Entertainment]] }} | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{Film date|2014|05|16|[[Seattle International Film Festival]]|2014|06|06|United States}} | runtime = 126 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 125:46--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/fault-our-stars-film | title=''The Fault in Our Stars'' (12A) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=May 8, 2014 | accessdate=November 16, 2014}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = {{Plainlist| * $12 million (gross)<ref name="FilmLA">{{cite web | url=http://filmla.com/uploads/2014_FeatureFilm_study_v8_WEB_1432830776.pdf | title=Feature Film Study | publisher=Film L.A. Inc. | date=2014 | accessdate=June 27, 2018}}</ref> * $8.5 million (net)<ref name="FilmLA" /> }} | gross = $307.2 million<ref name=BOM /> }} '''''The Fault in Our Stars''''' is a 2014 American [[Romance film|romantic]] [[Tragedy|tragedy film]]<ref>https://nypost.com/2014/06/04/the-fault-in-our-stars-glows-with-teen-tragedy/</ref><ref>https://www.dailydot.com/via/real-tragedy-fault-in-our-stars/</ref><ref>https://www.npr.org/2012/01/17/145343351/the-fault-in-our-stars-love-in-a-time-of-cancer</ref><ref>https://www.academia.edu/19840005/TRAGIC_ROMANCE_IN_THE_FAULT_IN_OUR_STARS_BY_JOHN_GREEN</ref> directed by [[Josh Boone (director)|Josh Boone]], based on [[The Fault in Our Stars|the 2012 novel of the same name]] by [[John Green (author)|John Green]]. The film stars [[Shailene Woodley]], [[Ansel Elgort]], [[Laura Dern]], [[Sam Trammell]], [[Nat Wolff]], and [[Willem Dafoe]] playing supporting roles. Woodley plays Hazel Grace Lancaster, a sixteen-year-old cancer patient who is forced by her parents to attend a support group, where she meets and subsequently falls in love with Augustus Waters, another cancer patient, played by Elgort.
Development of ''The Fault in Our Stars'' began in January 2012 when [[Fox 2000]], a division of [[20th Century Fox]], optioned the rights to adapt the novel into a feature film. Principal photography began on August 26, 2013, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, with a few additional days in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, before concluding on October 16, 2013. Pittsburgh doubled for all of the scenes set in Indianapolis, Indiana, the novel's setting, as well as for some interior scenes set in Amsterdam.
''The Fault in Our Stars'' was released in the United States on June 6, 2014, to positive critical reception, with praise given to Woodley's and Elgort's performances as well as the screenplay. The film was also a blockbuster, becoming number one at the box office during its opening weekend, and grossing over $307 million worldwide against a budget of $12 million. It was released on [[Blu-ray]] and [[DVD]] on September 16, 2014, and grossed over $42 million in total domestic video sales.<ref name="The Numbers">{{cite web|title=The Fault in Our Stars (2014)|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Fault-in-Our-Stars-The#tab=summary|website=The Numbers.|publisher=Nash Information Services, LLC.|accessdate=10 August 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918191530/http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Fault-in-Our-Stars-The | archivedate=18 September 2016}}</ref>
==Plot== <!-- Please see WP:FILMPLOT for more information. The word count in this section should be kept between 400-700 words. The plot summary does NOT intend to reproduce the experience of watching, nor is it meant to cover EVERY detail. It should serve as an overview of the major plot elements and events. PER WP:FILMPLOT, PLOT SUMMARIES FOR FEATURE FILMS AND TELEVISION SERIES SHOULD BE BETWEEN 400 AND 700 WORDS. See "Wikipedia:How to write a plot summary" (WP:PLOTSUM) for general guidelines.--> Hazel Grace Lancaster is a teenager living in Indianapolis, who has terminal [[thyroid cancer]] that has spread to her lungs. Believing she is depressed, her mother Frannie urges her to attend a weekly cancer patient [[support group]] to help her make friends with individuals who are going through the same thing. There Hazel meets Augustus Waters, a charming teenager who lost a leg to [[osteosarcoma|bone cancer]] but has since apparently been cancer-free. He invites Hazel to his house where they bond over their hobbies and agree to read each other's favorite books. Hazel recommends ''An Imperial Affliction'', a novel about a cancer-stricken girl named Anna that parallels her experience, and Augustus gives Hazel ''Counter Insurgence''. They keep in touch via text over the weeks that follow and grow closer. After Augustus finishes the book, he expresses frustration with its abrupt ending (it ends in the middle of a sentence). Hazel explains that the novel's mysterious author, Peter Van Houten ([[Willem Dafoe]]), retreated to [[Amsterdam]] following the novel's publication and has not been heard from since.
Weeks later, Augustus tells Hazel he has traced Van Houten's assistant, Lidewij, and has corresponded with Van Houten by email. She writes to him to find out more about the novel's ambiguous ending. Van Houten replies that he is only willing to answer her questions in person. Hazel asks her mother if she can travel to Amsterdam to visit him, but Frannie kindly refuses because of financial and medical constraints. Augustus suggests that she use the "cancer wish" she received from [[Make-A-Wish Foundation]] but Hazel explains that she has already used hers to visit [[Walt Disney World]]. Augustus and Hazel go on a picnic date and begin to fall in love. Augustus surprises Hazel with tickets to Amsterdam. After a medical setback, Hazel's doctors eventually agree to allow the trip, since they expect that she will soon become incapable of doing anything at all.
Hazel and Augustus arrive in Amsterdam and are presented with reservations at an expensive restaurant, pre-paid by Van Houten. During the meal, Augustus confesses his love for Hazel. The following afternoon, they go to Van Houten's house, but are shocked to find he is a mean-spirited alcoholic. Lidewij arranged the meeting and their dinner without Van Houten knowing anything about it. Angered by his assistant's actions, he taunts Hazel for seeking serious answers to a piece of fiction and belittles her medical condition. She leaves, utterly distraught. Lidewij invites them to go sightseeing to make up for their ruined experience. The three visit the [[Anne Frank House]], where Hazel struggles to climb the house's many stairs. They spend that night together in their hotel and have sex for the first time. The next day Augustus tells Hazel that his cancer has returned and spread throughout his body and is terminal. Hazel is heartbroken, expressing how unfair life can be.
After their return to [[Indianapolis]], Augustus' health worsens. He is taken to the [[Intensive care unit|ICU]] and realizes he is close to death. Augustus invites his blind best friend Isaac and Hazel to his pre-funeral, where they deliver eulogies that they have both prepared. Hazel tells him she would not trade their short time together for anything, since he "gave me a forever within the numbered days." Augustus dies eight days later and Hazel is astonished to find Van Houten at the funeral. He tells her that Augustus had demanded he attend his funeral to make up for the spoiled trip. Van Houten tells her that the novel is based on the experiences of his daughter Anna, who died from [[leukemia]] at a young age. He gives Hazel a piece of paper which she crumples up asking him to leave. Later, talking with Isaac, Hazel learns that Augustus had asked Van Houten to help him write a eulogy for her. She retrieves the crumpled paper and reads his words accepting his death and about his love for her. She lies on her back on her lawn looking up at the stars, smiling as she remembers Augustus and says: "Okay."
==Cast== {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 150 | footer = Top to bottom: [[Shailene Woodley]] stars as Hazel Grace Lancaster, [[Ansel Elgort]] as Augustus Waters, and [[Nat Wolff]] as Isaac in the film. | image1 = Shailene Woodley March 18, 2014 (cropped).jpg | alt1 = Shailene Woodley | image2 = Ansel Elgort (35875410045) (colour edited).jpg | alt2 = Ansel Elgort | image3 = Nat Wolff TIFF 2012.jpg | alt3 = Nat Wolff }} * [[Shailene Woodley]] as Hazel Grace Lancaster ** [[Lily Kenna]] as young Hazel<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sperling|first1=Nicole|title=As 'The Fault in Our Stars' is filmed, John Green turns astrologer|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2014/feb/15/entertainment/la-et-mn-john-green-fault-in-our-stars-20140216|accessdate=August 29, 2014|publisher=latimes.com|date=February 15, 2014}}</ref> * [[Ansel Elgort]] as Augustus "Gus" Waters<ref name="casting2" /> * [[Nat Wolff]] as Isaac, Augustus' best friend<ref name="casting3" /> * [[Laura Dern]] as Frannie Lancaster, Hazel's mother<ref name="casting3" /> * [[Sam Trammell]] as Michael Lancaster, Hazel's father<ref name="casting4" /> * [[Willem Dafoe]] as Peter Van Houten<ref name="casting6" /> * [[Lotte Verbeek]] as Lidewij Vliegenthart, Van Houten's assistant * [[Mike Birbiglia]] as Patrick, the Support Group leader<ref name="casting5" /> * Ana Dela Cruz as Dr. Maria * Milica Govich as Mrs. Waters, Augustus's mother * David Whalen as Mr. Waters, Augustus's father * [[Emily Peachey]] as Monica * Emily Bach as Monica's Mom * Carole Weyers (''voice'') as [[Anne Frank]]
==Production==
===Pre-production=== On January 31, 2012, it was announced that [[Fox 2000]], a division of [[20th Century Fox]], had optioned the rights to adapt [[John Green (author)|John Green]]'s novel ''[[The Fault in Our Stars]]'' for a feature film.<ref name="deahl">{{cite news |first=Rachel |last=Deahl |date=January 31, 2012 |title=Fox Options John Green's 'Fault in Our Stars' |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/childrens/childrens-industry-news/article/50442-fox-options-john-green-s-fault-in-our-stars.html |magazine=[[Publishers Weekly]] |accessdate=July 23, 2013 }}</ref> [[Wyck Godfrey]] and Marty Bowen were due to produce the film with their production company, [[Temple Hill Entertainment]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Abrams|first1=Rachel|title=Fox 2000 options ‘Fault in Our Stars’|url=https://variety.com/2012/film/news/fox-2000-options-fault-in-our-stars-1118049583/|accessdate=August 10, 2014|publisher=variety.com|date=February 1, 2012}}</ref> [[Stephen Chbosky]], who directed ''[[The Perks of Being a Wallflower (film)|The Perks of Being a Wallflower]]'' (also filmed in Pittsburgh), was in talks to direct the film but turned it down because of its similarity to ''Perks''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hypable.com/perks-author-stephen-chbosky-says-he-had-a-meeting-to-direct-the-fault-in-our-stars-movie/|title=Stephen Chbosky says he met about directing Fault In Our Stars movie|work=Hypable | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918200002/http://www.hypable.com/perks-author-stephen-chbosky-says-he-had-a-meeting-to-direct-the-fault-in-our-stars-movie/ | archivedate=18 September 2016}}</ref> On February 19, 2013, [[Josh Boone (director)|Josh Boone]] was hired as director;<ref name=Director>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|last2=Lewis|first2=Andy|title='The Fault in Our Stars' Movie Lands Director|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fault-stars-movie-lands-director-422485|accessdate=August 10, 2014|publisher=hollywoodreporter.com|date=February 19, 2013}}</ref> [[Scott Neustadter]] and [[Michael H. Weber]] were hired to adapt the novel into a screenplay{{mdash}}their second adaptation for Fox, following ''[[Rosaline]]''.<ref name="Director" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Fleming Jr|first1=Mike|title=Fox 2000 Sets Neustadter & Weber To Adapt ‘The Fault In Our Stars’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/03/fox-2000-sets-neustadter-weber-to-adapt-the-fault-in-our-stars/|accessdate=August 10, 2014|publisher=deadline.com|date=March 28, 2012}}</ref>
===Casting=== On March 19, 2013, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' announced that Shailene Woodley (who had recently been cast in, and was filming, ''[[Divergent (film)|Divergent]]'') would play Hazel Grace Lancaster.<ref name=casting1>{{cite web|author=Sara Vilkomerson|title=Shailene Woodley offered lead role for 'The Fault in Our Stars'|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/03/19/shailene-woodley-fault-in-our-stars/|publisher=''Entertainment Weekly''|date=March 19, 2013|accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref> Director Josh Boone said: "We read close to 150 actresses for the role, and I saw about 50 of those. Within ten or fifteen seconds of Shailene's audition, I knew she was Hazel. She held up her script pages and just her eyes were peeking over them."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Fault in Our Stars — Movie Production Notes|url=http://www.cinemareview.com/production.asp?prodid=18394|publisher=CinemaReview.com|accessdate=August 13, 2014}}</ref> On May 10, 2013, [[Ansel Elgort]] was cast as Hazel's love interest, Augustus Waters.<ref name=casting2>{{cite news|last1=Sneider|first1=Jeff|title=‘Divergent’ Star Ansel Elgort to Join Shailene Woodley in ‘The Fault In Our Stars’|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/column-post/divergent-star-ansel-elgort-join-shailene-woodley-fault-our-stars-90881/|accessdate=August 11, 2014|publisher=thewrap.com|date=May 10, 2013}}</ref> On July 23, [[Laura Dern]] joined the cast as Hazel's mother Frannie Lancaster, and [[Nat Wolff]] as Issac, Augustus' best friend.<ref name=casting3>{{cite news |first=Sara |last=Vilkomerson |date=July 23, 2013 |title=Nat Wolff cast as Isaac in 'The Fault in Our Stars' |magazine=Entertainment Weekly |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/07/23/nat-wolff-fault-in-our-stars-isaac |accessdate=July 23, 2013 }}</ref> Wolff told [[HuffPost Live]]: "It's exciting, I feel really lucky. The fact that I get to work with these super talented people{{mdash}}I mean, that's part of the reason why, I'm good in the movie, that's the reason."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tess Katz|first1=Emily|title=Nat Wolff Explains Why He Was Cast In 'The Fault In Our Stars'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/29/nat-wolff-the-fault-in-our-stars_n_5411423.html|accessdate=August 11, 2014|publisher=huffingtonpost.com|date=May 29, 2014}}</ref> On August 14, [[Sam Trammell]] was cast as Hazel's father Michael Lancaster,<ref name=casting4>{{cite news|last1=Sneider|first1=Jeff|title=‘True Blood's’ Sam Trammell Joins Shailene Woodley in ‘The Fault in Our Stars’|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/column-post/true-bloods-sam-trammell-joins-shailene-woodley-fault-our-stars-exclusive-110821/|accessdate=August 11, 2013|publisher=thewrap.com|date=August 14, 2013}}</ref> and on August 28, author John Green announced that [[Mike Birbiglia]] would be playing Patrick.<ref name=casting5>{{cite news|last1=Green|first1=John|title=Mike Birbiglia will play Patrick|url=https://twitter.com/realjohngreen/statuses/372831664281772032|accessdate=August 29, 2014|publisher=twitter.com|date=August 28, 2013}}</ref> On September 6, he tweeted that [[Willem Dafoe]] would play Peter van Houten.<ref name=casting6>{{cite news|last1=Bahr|first1=Lindsey|title=Willem Dafoe cast as Peter Van Houten in 'The Fault in Our Stars'|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/09/06/willem-dafoe-the-fault-in-our-stars/|accessdate=August 29, 2014|publisher=ew.com|date=September 6, 2013}}</ref>
Prior to these announcements, author John Green had tweeted that he would be happy if [[Mae Whitman]] played Hazel,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lamoureux|first1=Jen|title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’ casting: Who should play Hazel?|url=http://www.hypable.com/2012/11/19/the-fault-in-our-stars-casting-who-should-play-hazel/|accessdate=August 10, 2014|publisher=hypable.com|date=November 19, 2012}}</ref> and in February 2013, there had been speculation that Shailene Woodley and [[Hailee Steinfeld]] were among those being considered for the lead role.<ref name="Director" />
John Green filmed a [[cameo appearance]]; his scene was cut from the film but is included in the deleted scenes section of the film's DVD and Blu-ray releases. In the cut scene, Green plays the father of a young girl who asks about Hazel's [[cannula]] while at the airport.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jaimie Etkin |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jaimieetkin/heres-your-first-look-at-john-greens-the-fault-in-our-stars |title=Here's Your First Look At John Green's "The Fault In Our Stars" Cameo |publisher=Buzzfeed.com |accessdate=June 6, 2014|date=May 27, 2014}}</ref> Green said: "They cut [the scene] because it was totally unnecessary to the movie-slash-I was terrible."<ref name=vulture-interview>{{cite news|last1=Vineyard|first1=Jennifer|title=Summer Movie Preview 2014: John Green on The Fault in Our Stars and the Magic of Shailene Woodley|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/04/john-green-interview-fault-in-our-stars-shailene-woodley.html|accessdate=August 29, 2014|publisher=vulture.com|date=April 29, 2014}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began on August 26, 2013, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Christine|title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’ filming in Pittsburgh (Filming Locations Open Thread)|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/tag/the-fault-in-our-stars-filming-in-pittsburgh/|publisher=On Location Vacations|accessdate=April 17, 2014|date=August 26, 2013}}</ref> Film locations included Oakmont, Pennsylvania,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dezayas|first1=Heidi|title='Fault in Our Stars' begins filming at Oakmont home|url=http://triblive.com/neighborhoods/yourallekiskivalley/yourallekiskivalleymore/4604340-74/street-movie-oakmont#axzz39rVqxylw|accessdate=August 9, 2014|publisher=triblive.com|date=August 28, 2014}}</ref> [[UPMC Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh]], and the historic The Mansions on Fifth hotel.<ref>{{cite news|last=Payne |first=Sara |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/movies/2014/05/07/When-movies-film-in-Pittsburgh-experiences-vary/stories/201405070066 |title=When movies film in Pittsburgh, experiences vary — Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |publisher=Post-gazette.com |date=May 6, 2014 |accessdate=May 23, 2014}}</ref> The church scenes were filmed at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Pittsburgh suburb of Mt. Lebanon.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yiin|first1=Wesley|title=Mt. Lebanon church channels Hollywood with 'Fault in Our Stars' screening|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/2014/06/06/Church-channels-Hollywood-with-Fault-screening/stories/201406060103|accessdate=August 9, 2014|publisher=post-gazette.com|date=June 6, 2014}}</ref> Filming in Pennsylvania continued until October 10,<ref>{{cite news|title=Production Exclusive – Filming Wraps on "The Fault in Our Stars" Movie Adaptation|url=http://trulyluminary.com/2013/10/18/production-exclusive-filming-wraps-on-the-fault-in-our-stars-movie-adaptation/|accessdate=August 9, 2014|publisher=trulyluminary.com|date=October 18, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810061739/http://trulyluminary.com/2013/10/18/production-exclusive-filming-wraps-on-the-fault-in-our-stars-movie-adaptation/|archivedate=August 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> then the production moved to Amsterdam, where filming began on October 14.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Christine|title=The Fault In Our Stars moves from Pittsburgh to Amsterdam|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2013/10/15/the-fault-in-our-stars-moves-from-pittsburgh-to-amsterdam/|accessdate=August 9, 2014|publisher=onlocationvacations.com|date=October 15, 2013}}</ref> Filming was officially completed on October 16, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Green|first1=John|title=Last day with my Gus|url=https://twitter.com/realjohngreen/statuses/390568840285155328|publisher=twitter.com|accessdate=9 August 2014}}</ref>
In Amsterdam, three days of filming took place. Woodley and Elgort were filmed on a canal-side public bench. On July 2, 2014, ''The Guardian'' reported that the bench had gone missing, and city officials said they did not know where it was. Amsterdam city spokesman, Stephan van der Hoek said: "It's a bit embarrassing, because we do keep good track of them, but it's gone all right". He promised to install a new bench within weeks.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Beaumont-Thomas|first1=Ben|title=Bench from The Fault in Our Stars goes missing in Amsterdam|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/jul/02/the-fault-in-our-stars-bench-missing-amsterdam|accessdate=August 9, 2014|publisher=theguardian.com|date=July 2, 2014}}</ref> Just a week later, ''Entertainment Weekly'' said the Amsterdam film office had tweeted a photograph taken during the re-installation of the stolen bench; Amsterdam film commissioner Simon Brester said it was the same bench, not a replacement.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McHenry|first1=Jackson|title=The 'Fault in Our Stars' bench is back in Amsterdam|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2014/07/07/tfios-bench-amsterdam/|accessdate=September 30, 2014|publisher=ew.com|date=July 7, 2014}}</ref>
Filming in Pittsburgh included the interior scenes at the Anne Frank House, which was recreated on a soundstage at Pittsburgh Studios located in Churchill Borough, Pennsylvania in the east suburbs of Pittsburgh.<ref>President of Churchill Borough</ref> Production designer Molly Hughes and art director Greg Weimerskirch built three different studio sets in Pittsburgh, one for each floor.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/how-the-fault-in-our-stars-recreated-the-anne-frank-house-1201214609/ | work=Variety | first=Ramin | last=Setoodeh | title=How 'The Fault in Our Stars' Recreated the Anne Frank House | date=June 6, 2014}}</ref> Also, the [[Funky Bones]] art monument in Indianapolis was recreated in Pittsburgh with the help of the sculpture's creator, Dutch artist Joep Van Lieshout.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/story/entertainment/movies/2013/08/30/the-fault-in-our-stars-movie-written-here-set-here-shot-where-/2742803/|title='Fault' movie written here, set here, shot where?|date=August 31, 2013|work=Indianapolis Star}}</ref>
Author John Green, though an Indianapolis native, was pleased with the selection of Pittsburgh for filming. He commented that<blockquote> Pittsburgh has an amazing community of really talented film professionals that’s been built up over the last 20 years. I’ve been blown away by their professionalism, their confidence, their dedication. There aren’t a lot of cities like that. You kind of have to find the city that can be Indianapolis. And Pittsburgh, even though it has a lot of hills, it can be Indianapolis. We just have to find a couple of flat streets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/Best-of-the-Burgh-Blogs/The-412/October-2013/QA-The-Fault-in-Our-Stars-Author-John-Green/#sthash.CQwZmVIp.dpuf|title=Q+A: 'The Fault in Our Stars' Author John Green|work=pittsburghmagazine.com}}</ref></blockquote>
===Music=== {{main article|The Fault in Our Stars (soundtrack)}} [[Mike Mogis]] and [[Nate Walcott]] of [[Bright Eyes (band)|Bright Eyes]] [[Film score|scored]] the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hypable.com/2013/07/09/fault-in-our-stars-movie-score-bright-eyes/|title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’ movie to be scored by Bright Eyes|last=Sims|first=Andrew|publisher=Hypable|accessdate=April 17, 2014|date=July 9, 2013}}</ref> The full album track list was released on April 13, 2014, featuring songs from artists including: [[M83 (band)|M83]], [[Grouplove]], [[Kodaline]], [[Jake Bugg]], [[Tom Odell]], [[Birdy (singer)|Birdy]], [[Ed Sheeran]] and [[Charli XCX]], who performed "[[Boom Clap]]", one of the main songs from the movie, which became an international success, due in part to its exposure in the film.<ref>{{cite news|title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’ Soundtrack Details|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/04/13/the-fault-in-our-stars-soundtrack-details/|accessdate=August 29, 2014|publisher=filmmusicreporter.com|date=April 13, 2014}}</ref> The soundtrack was released by [[Atlantic Records]] on May 19 in the U.S., and on June 23 in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’ Score Album Details|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/06/23/the-fault-in-our-stars-score-album-details/|accessdate=August 29, 2014|publisher=filmmusicreporter.com|date=June 23, 2014}}</ref>
==Release== ''The Fault in Our Stars'' [[Film premiere|premiered]] to 300 guests at the [[Ziegfeld Theater]] in New York City on June 2, 2014. At the premiere, Green said: "I didn't want to sell it, because Hollywood sucks at making unsentimental movies about illness."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Setoodeh|first1=Ramin|title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’ Premiere: Even Shailene Woodley Admits to Crying|url=https://variety.com/2014/scene/news/the-fault-in-our-stars-premiere-even-shailene-woodley-admits-to-crying-1201210174/|accessdate=September 23, 2014|publisher=variety.com|date=June 3, 2014}}</ref> The film was released on June 6, 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2013/10/08/john-green-social-media-tfios/2944079/ | title='The Fault In Our Stars' movie gets a release date | work=[[USA Today]] | date=October 8, 2013 | accessdate=October 10, 2013 | last=Deutsch |first=Lindsay}}</ref> After the New York premiere, Evangeline Earl, a student, announced that Green's book, from which the film was adapted, had been inspired by her sister Esther Earl, who had also been an author. Esther had thyroid cancer and died in 2010. Evangeline said Esther had met Green at [[LeakyCon]], a [[Harry Potter]] convention held in Boston in 2009. Green said, "I could never have written ''The Fault in Our Stars'' without knowing Esther. Every word on that book depends on her."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Earl|first1=Evangeline|title=My sister Esther inspired ‘The Fault in Our Stars.’ The movie is her sequel.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/my-sister-esther-inspired-the-fault-in-our-stars-the-movie-is-her-sequel/2014/06/12/504c2ca4-efef-11e3-914c-1fbd0614e2d4_story.html|accessdate=September 23, 2014|publisher=washingtonpost.com|date=June 12, 2014}}</ref> Green said he used the word "okay" in the book and the film because Hazel and Augustus used it to express their love for each other;<ref>{{cite web|title=Questions about The Fault in Our Stars (Spoilers!) |url=http://johngreenbooks.com/questions-about-the-fault-in-our-stars-spoilers/ |publisher=johngreenbooks.com |accessdate=September 25, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141005184550/http://johngreenbooks.com/questions-about-the-fault-in-our-stars-spoilers/ |archivedate=October 5, 2014 |df= }}</ref> it becomes a special word between them. The original novel was inspired by the late author [[Esther Earl]], who used the word "okay" with her sister Abigail.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Payne|first1=Will|title='I may never get to kiss a boy': Parents of cancer victim, 16, who inspired hit film The Fault in Our Stars reveal she dreamed of a boyfriend just like movie's Gus|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2656487/EXCLUSIVE-Oh-I-never-kiss-boy-Parents-16-year-old-inspired-teen-cancer-victim-Hazel-Grace-A-Fault-Our-Stars-reveal-daughter-dreamed-boyfriend-like-Gus.html|accessdate=September 26, 2014|publisher=dailymail.co.uk|date=June 12, 2014|location=London}}</ref>
===Marketing=== The first [[Trailer (promotion)|trailer]] was released on January 29, 2014. The trailer had over 3 million views in less than 24 hours,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-et-jc-the-fault-in-our-stars-movie-trailer-book-on-top-20140130,0,3851891.story#axzz2rwahqgXr | title='The Fault in Our Stars' movie trailer hits; the book is on top | work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] | date=January 30, 2014 | accessdate=January 30, 2014 | last=Kellogg |first=Carolyn}}</ref> and more than 15 million views in its first seven days. A video clip was shown before the show at the [[2014 MTV Movie Awards]] on April 13.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wickman|first=Kase|title=This 'Fault In Our Stars' Clip Hits Us Right In The Feelings Bone|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1726041/the-fault-in-our-stars-mtv-movie-awards-exclusive.jhtml|accessdate=April 14, 2014|newspaper=mtv.com|date=April 13, 2014}}</ref> An extended trailer was released on April 28, and Fox released more clips via [[YouTube]] as part of the film's pre-release promotion.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Strecker|first1=Erin|title=New 'Fault in Our Stars' trailer: More tears, more laughs, more pot?|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/04/28/fault-in-our-stars-trailer/|accessdate=August 29, 2014|publisher=ew.com|date=April 28, 2014}}</ref> On April 2, the studio announced the launch of a promotional tour program named Demand Our Stars. Green, Woodley, Elgort, and Wolff would visit the states that got most votes from fans re-blogging their states' map outlines.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sims|first1=Andrew|title=John Green and the ‘Fault’ movie cast to go on nationwide tour, vote for your city to receive a visit|url=http://www.hypable.com/2014/04/02/fault-in-our-stars-movie-tour-john-green-shailene-woodley/|accessdate=August 9, 2014|publisher=hypable.com|date=April 2, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141026042034/http://www.hypable.com/2014/04/02/fault-in-our-stars-movie-tour-john-green-shailene-woodley/|archivedate=October 26, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Four states won: the tour program started in Miami, Florida, on May 6; went to Cleveland, Ohio, on May 7; then went to Nashville, Tennessee, on May 8; and ended in Dallas, Texas, on May 9.<ref>{{cite web|title=Demand Our Stars Tour — May 6-May 9|url=http://thefaultinourstarsmovie.com/faq-demandourstars|publisher=thefaultinourstarsmovie.com|accessdate=August 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Christine|title=Meet the cast of ‘The Fault In Our Stars’ in a city near you this week|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2014/05/06/meet-the-cast-of-the-fault-in-our-stars-in-a-city-near-you-this-week/|accessdate=August 10, 2014|publisher=onlocationvacations.com|date=May 6, 2014}}</ref>
===Home media=== ''The Fault in Our Stars'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on September 16, 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00LTA0JBU |title=The Fault In Our Stars |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |accessdate=August 3, 2014}}</ref> ''The Fault in Our Stars: Little Infinities'' Blu-ray edition features the theatrical 126-minute and extended 133-minute versions of the film, a number of [[deleted scene]]s including the John Green cameo, and featurettes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dvdblurayfeatures.com/the-fault-in-our-stars-special-features-comparison-little-infinities-extended-edition-blu-ray-combo-pack-dvd-versions-bonus-extras/|title=The Fault In Our Stars Special Features Comparison (Blu-ray / DVD Versions)|publisher=dvdblurayfeatures.com|accessdate=October 18, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918202800/http://dvdblurayfeatures.com/the-fault-in-our-stars-special-features-comparison-little-infinities-extended-edition-blu-ray-combo-pack-dvd-versions-bonus-extras/ | archivedate=18 September 2016}}</ref> The home video release grossed over $42.6 million in total domestic video sales.<ref name="The Numbers" />
==Reception==
===Critical response=== {{quote box|width=25%|quote="Big movies have their embedded lessons in heroism, but it's nice to have tales of human-scale fortitude."|source=—Lisa Kennedy, writing for ''Denver Post''<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Lisa|title=Review: "The Fault in Our Stars"|url=http://www.denverpost.com/movies/ci_25899282/review-fault-our-stars|accessdate=September 28, 2014|publisher=denverpost.com|date=June 6, 2014}}</ref>}} ''The Fault in Our Stars'' received generally positive reviews, with praise aimed at Woodley's and Elgort's performances, and the screenplay.{{fact|date=January 2018}} On [[review aggregator]] [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 80% based on 209 reviews, with an average rating of 6.9/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Wise, funny, and heartbreaking without resorting to exploitation, ''The Fault in Our Stars'' does right by its bestselling source material."<ref name="tomatoes" /> [[Metacritic]] gave the film a score of 69 out of 100, based on 45 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews."<ref name="metacritic" /> At [[CinemaScore]] opening day audiences gave the film an "A" on an A+ to F scale.<ref>{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-fault-stars-eyes-710051|title=Box Office: 'Fault in Our Stars' Eyes Stunning $52M-Plus Debut, Crushes 'Edge of Tomorrow'|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter |date=June 7, 2014|accessdate=July 9, 2014}}</ref>
[[Steven Rea]] of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' gave the film a score of 3 out of 4; he said: "Woodley ... balances grace with gravity, wit with heart."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rea|first1=Steven|title='The Fault in Our Stars': Tale of dying teens in love a terrific tear-jerker|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/entertainment/20140606__The_Fault_in_Our_Stars___Tale_of_dying_teens_in_love_a_terrific_tear-jerker.html|accessdate=September 28, 2014|publisher=philly.com|date=June 5, 2014}}</ref> [[A. O. Scott]] writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'' said: "The film sets out to make you weep{{mdash}}not just sniffle or choke up a little, but sob until your nose runs and your face turns blotchy. It succeeds."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=A.O.|title=Young Love, Complicated by Cancer|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/06/movies/the-fault-in-our-stars-sets-out-to-make-you-cry.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&_r=0|accessdate=September 28, 2014|publisher=nytimes.com|date=June 5, 2014}}</ref> ''[[The Boston Globe]]'s'' [[Ty Burr]] gave the film a rating of 2.5 out 4 and said: "If Elgort's Gus is glibly charming and ultimately affecting, ''The Fault in Our Stars'' belongs to Woodley, a performer who always seems to be backing warily into her own movies."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burr|first1=Ty|title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’ works to be earnest|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/2014/06/05/the-fault-our-stars-works-earnest/9qqdfep4uMSu1KRz1egL2N/story.html|accessdate=September 28, 2014|date=June 5, 2014}}</ref>
[[Quickflix]]'s Simon Miraudo rated the film 3/5, and said: "''The Fault in Our Stars'' undeniably sets us up to knock us down."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quickflix.com.au/news/reviews/TheFaultinOurStars |title=The Fault in Our Stars Review|author= Simon Miraudo| publisher=Quickflix |date=May 28, 2014 |accessdate=June 6, 2014}}</ref> [[Richard Roeper]] of ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film 4 stars. He said Woodley's performance as Hazel was "transcendent, pure and authentic", stating that, "she's that memorable."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Roeper|first1=Richard|title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’: A lovely work led by the transcendent Shailene Woodley|url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/movies/27856994-421/the-fault-in-our-stars-a-lovely-work-led-by-the-transcendent-shailene-woodley.html|accessdate=September 24, 2014|publisher=suntimes.com|date=June 4, 2014}}</ref> Scott Mendelson of ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine said the film is "exceptionally high-quality mainstream entertainment" and called it "a genuine work of art."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mendelson|first1=Scott|title=Review: Shailene Woodley's 'Fault In Our Stars' Is A Generational Classic|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/06/05/review-shailene-woodleys-fault-in-our-stars-is-a-generational-classic/|accessdate=September 24, 2014|publisher=forbes.com|date=June 5, 2014}}</ref> Anna Smith of ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' said it was a, "touching romance and Shailene Woodley's best performance yet."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Anna|title=The Fault In Our Stars|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=138467|accessdate=September 25, 2014|publisher=empireonline.com}}</ref> Emma Dibdin of [[Digital Spy]] wrote "''The Fault in Our Stars'' is a sharp and emotionally-sophisticated weepie that imbues its teenage characters with rare intelligence, and tackles its bleak subject matter with acerbic wit and tenderness."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dibdin|first1=Emma|title=The Fault in Our Stars review: An acerbic and sophisticated weepie|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/review/a577580/the-fault-in-our-stars-review-an-acerbic-and-sophisticated-weepie.html|accessdate=September 25, 2014|publisher=digitalspy.co.uk|date=June 16, 2014}}</ref> Andy Lea of the ''[[Daily Star (British newspaper)|Daily Star]]'' said: "as teen romances go, this is powerful stuff."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lea|first1=Andy|title=Review and trailer: The Fault In Our Stars (12A) is a touching teen romance|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/movies/383847/Review-and-trailer-The-Fault-In-Our-Stars-12A-is-a-touching-teen-romance|accessdate=September 25, 2014|publisher=dailystar.co.uk|date=June 15, 2014}}</ref> Wilson Morales at ''BlackFilm.com'' praised Woodley and Elgort's performances, saying they: "are so captivating and genuine in their performances, they manage to make this intensely poignant film very moving, romantic and highly entertaining."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morales|first1=Wilson|title=The Fault In Our Stars|url=http://www.blackfilm.com/read/2014/06/the-fault-in-our-stars-film-review/|accessdate=September 25, 2014|publisher=blackfilm.com|date=June 7, 2014}}</ref>
{{quote box|width=25%|align=left|quote="It's a fresh, lively love story, brimming with humor and heartbreak, and lifted to the heights by Shailene Woodley, a sublime actress with a résumé that pretty much proves she's incapable of making a false move on camera."|source=—Peter Travers of ''Rolling Stone''<ref>{{cite web|first=Peter |last=Travers |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/the-fault-in-our-stars-20140605 |title='The Fault in Our Stars' Movie Review |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=May 27, 2011 |accessdate=June 6, 2014}}</ref>}} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's Richard Corliss wrote: "Hazel and Augustus will live in film lore because of the young actors who play them."<ref>{{cite news|first=Richard |last=Corliss |url=http://time.com/2822847/the-fault-in-our-stars-movie-review/ |title=The Fault In Our Stars Review: Shailene Woodley and Ansel Elgort |publisher=Time |accessdate=June 6, 2014 |date=June 5, 2014}}</ref> Chris Vongar of ''[[Dallas Morning News]]'' gave the film a B+ as "the movie is witty and alive and only very occasionally maudlin."<ref>{{cite news|last=Vognar |first=Chris |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/20140605-the-fault-in-our-stars-hits-the-big-screen-with-its-best-qualities-intact-b.ece |title=‘The Fault in Our Stars’ hits the big screen with its best qualities intact (B+) |newspaper=Dallas Morning News |date=June 5, 2014 |accessdate=June 6, 2014}}</ref> ''[[USA Today (magazine)|USA Today]]''{{'}}s Claudia Puig called the film "well-written, well-acted, acerbic, funny and wisely observed", giving it 3.5 out of 4.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Puig|first1=Claudia|title='The Fault in Our Stars' is nearly flawless|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/06/04/the-fault-in-our-stars-review/9630351|accessdate=September 25, 2014|publisher=usatoday.com|date=June 4, 2014}}</ref> Chris Nashawaty of ''Entertainment Weekly'' called the film a "funny, sweet, three-hankie tearjerker" and gave the B grade.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nashawaty|first1=Chris|title=The Fault in Our Stars Movie Review|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20811434_20822906,00.html|accessdate=August 12, 2014|publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=June 12, 2014}}</ref> [[Geoff Pevere]] of ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' said, "While it may not conform to one's real-life expectations it certainly hews tightly to teen-flick conventions."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pevere|first1=Geoff|title=The Fault in Our Stars: a full-throttle, by-the-numbers tearjerker|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/film-reviews/the-fault-in-our-stars/article19009235|accessdate=September 24, 2014|publisher=theglobeandmail.com|date=June 6, 2014|location=Toronto}}</ref> Connie Ogle of ''[[The Miami Herald]]'' called it a, "sweet, romantic film full of sudden warmth and humor."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ogle|first1=Connie|title='The Fault in Our Stars' (PG-13)|url=http://www.miami.com/039the-fault-our-stars039-pg-13-article|accessdate=September 25, 2014|publisher=miami.com|date=June 5, 2014}}</ref> A.A. Dowd of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the film a "B" saying that it is, "blessed with sparks of wit and buoyed by the talents of a charismatic cast."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dowd|first1=A.A.|title=The Fault In Our Stars: Review|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/fault-our-stars-moves-page-screen-losing-little-it-205411|accessdate=September 25, 2014|publisher=avclub.com|date=June 5, 2014}}</ref>
[[Peter Bradshaw]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave the film a negative review, likening it to "being mugged by a professional whose skills in mixed martial arts you can't help but notice and appreciate, even as you are savagely beaten, then dragged upright, bruised and bleeding, and forced to watch as your assailant gives fully 45% of your money to charity."<ref>{{cite news |last=Bradshaw |first=Peter |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/jun/19/fault-in-our-stars-review-john-green |title=The Fault in our Stars review – manipulative and crass |date=June 19, 2014 |accessdate=June 19, 2014 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> [[Christy Lemire]] writing for [[Roger Ebert]]'s website gave it two stars out of four and criticized the film for being "emotionally inert, despite its many moments that are meant to put a lump in our throats." Lemire criticized Elgort's performance and praised Woodley's "abiding, disarming naturalism."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lemire|first1=Christy|title=The Fault in Our Stars Movie Review by Christy Lemire|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/the-fault-in-our-stars-2014|accessdate=September 25, 2014|publisher=rogerebert.com|date=June 6, 2014}}</ref> [[Robbie Collin]] writing for ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' said: "Gus is something of a manic pixie dreamboat: the lesser-spotted male version of the kooky, adoring girlfriend-type sometimes played by [[Kirsten Dunst]], [[Natalie Portman]], and [[Zooey Deschanel]]."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Collin|first1=Robbie|title=The Fault in Our Stars, film review: 'tenderly performed'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/10904822/The-Fault-in-Our-Stars-film-review-tenderly-performed.html |accessdate=August 12, 2014 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=June 17, 2014 |location=London}}</ref> [[David Edelstein]] of [[NPR]] said: <blockquote>I know people who cried at the trailer of the romantic teen cancer movie ''The Fault in Our Stars''{{mdash}}at the movie they'll need a life preserver to keep from drowning in a flood of tears. Me, I didn't cry, though at times my tear ducts tingled; I was on the verge. The film is a little slick for my taste, too engineered. But it's gently directed by Josh Boone and beautifully acted. Whatever the faults, it's not in the stars.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Edelstein |first1=David |title=Beautiful Acting Aside, It Isn't Hard To Find Fault In 'Our Stars' |url=https://www.npr.org/2014/06/06/319494198/beautiful-acting-aside-it-isnt-hard-to-find-fault-in-our-stars |accessdate=August 12, 2014 |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=June 6, 2014}}</ref></blockquote> Shalini Langer of ''[[The Indian Express]]'' gave the film two and a half stars and said: "The film is faithful to a fault from the dialogues to the clothes, the setting and the food, even while skipping over some of the unpleasant details."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Langer|first1=Shalini|title=The Fault in Our Stars film review|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/movie-review/the-fault-in-our-stars-film-review/99/|accessdate=August 12, 2014|publisher=[[The Indian Express]]|date=July 4, 2014}}</ref> [[Dana Stevens (critic)|Dana Stevens]] writing for ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate Magazine]]'' said: "What in the name of God is wrong with me that I didn't cry once{{mdash}}I, who just the day before wept through the entirety of my child's thoroughly upbeat school play."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stevens|first1=Dana|title=The Fault In Our Stars|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/movies/2014/06/the_fault_in_our_stars_starring_shailene_woodley_reviewed.html|accessdate=September 24, 2014|publisher=slate.com|date=June 6, 2014}}</ref>
Two Christian reviewers<ref>{{cite web|last=Baird|first=David|title=''The Fault in Our Stars''|url=http://www.thinkingfaith.org/articles/fault-our-stars|website=Thinking Faith|publisher=Jesuits in Britain|date=June 27, 2014|accessdate=July 7, 2014}}</ref> and some theologians<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mena|first1=Adelaide|title='The Fault in Our Stars' hailed for themes on suffering, love|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/the-fault-in-our-stars-hailed-for-themes-on-suffering-love-92623/|website=catholicnewsagency.com|publisher=Catholic News Agenchy|accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> have mentioned the presence of Christian themes in the film. Writing for [[Catholic News Agency]], [[Robert Barron (priest)|Robert Barron]] said:<blockquote> I don’t think it is the least bit accidental that Waters (Gus’s last name) and Grace (Hazel’s middle name) met in the sacred heart of Christ and thereby, despite their shared suffering, managed to give life to one another ... [and so] Hazel effectively repudiates her nihilism and materialism as she responds across the barrier of death to Gus’s 'okay'{{space}}." He also noted: "[Is] this film a satisfying presentation of Christianity? Hardly. But for those who are struggling to find their way to meaning and faith, it's not an entirely bad place to start."<ref name=catholicnewsagency>{{cite news|last1=Barron|first1=Robert|title='The Fault in Our Stars' and the Sacred Heart of Jesus|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/column.php?n=2930|accessdate=September 23, 2014|publisher=catholicnewsagency.com|date=July 1, 2014}}</ref></blockquote>
The film's studio, 20th Century Fox, mounted an unsuccessful campaign to have Shailene Woodley nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]], as well as the film's adapted screenplay.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/11/20/the-case-for-shailene-woodleys-fault-in-our-stars-oscar-nomination/ | work=Forbes | first=Scott | last=Mendelson | title=Why Shailene Woodley In 'Fault In Our Stars' Deserves An Oscar Nod}}</ref>
===Box office=== ''The Fault in Our Stars'' earned $124.9 million in North America and $182.3 million in other countries for a worldwide total of $307.2 million, against a production budget of $12 million.<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url= http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=faultinourstars.htm |title= The Fault In Our Stars (2014) |publisher= [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate = November 11, 2014}}</ref>
In North America, the film's income received a boost from "The Night Before Our Stars," a premium-priced event for which tickets sold for up to $25. The event included a screening of the film and a simulcast question-and-answer session with cast and crew, including Woodley, Elgort, Wolff, and Green.<ref name=BOMJune05>{{cite web|last=Subers|first=Ray|title=Forecast: 'Fault' to Push Cruise to the 'Edge' of the Box Office|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3853|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|date=June 5, 2014}}</ref> The film earned $8.2 million from Thursday-night showings and $26.1 million on its opening day.<ref name=BOMJune07>{{cite web|last=Subers|first=Ray|title=Friday Report: 'Fault' Shines, 'Edge' Flatlines on Friday|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3854|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|date=June 7, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://deadline.com/2014/06/the-fault-in-our-stars-stellar-8-2m-in-late-nights-edge-of-tomorrow-1-8m-741250/ | title = Updated: ‘The Fault In Our Stars’ Spectacular Friday, Matinees Exceptional, Stellar $8.2M Thursday; ‘Edge Of Tomorrow’ Yesterday’s News | author = Anita Busch | publisher = Deadline.com | date = June 6, 2014 | accessdate = December 9, 2014}}</ref> During its opening weekend, the film earned $48,002,573 from 3,173 theaters at an average of $15,128 per theater, making it number one in North America.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lang|first1=Brent|title=Box Office: ‘Fault in Our Stars’ Soars Past Tom Cruise With $48.2 Mil|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/box-office-fault-in-our-stars-soars-past-tom-cruise-with-48-2-mil-1201215870/|accessdate=September 24, 2014|publisher=variety.com|date=June 8, 2014}}</ref>
At locations outside North America, ''The Fault in Our Stars'' earned $16.59 million from 2,892 screens in 17 markets in its opening weekend, placing at number four behind ''[[Edge of Tomorrow (film)|Edge of Tomorrow]]'' ($81 million), ''[[Maleficent]]'' ($61.7 million), and ''[[X-Men: Days of Future Past]]'' ($41.1 million). Brazil, Mexico, and Australia generated the highest income with $5.8 million, $3.8 million, and $3.7 million respectively.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://deadline.com/2014/06/intl-box-office-edge-of-tomorrow-no-1-with-82m-fault-in-our-stars-shines-in-brazil-mexico-oz-maleficent-adds-59-7m-x-men-crosses-100m-in-china-more-2-786479/ | title = Intl Box Office: ‘Edge Of Tomorrow’ No. 1 With $81M; ‘Fault In Our Stars’ Shines Bright In Brazil, Mexico, Oz; ‘Maleficent’ Adds $61.7M; ‘X-Men’ Crosses $100M In China; More | author = Nancy Tartaglione | publisher = Deadline.com | date = June 9, 2014 | accessdate = December 9, 2014}}</ref> The following week the film earned $16.1 million from 40 markets, remaining at number 4 again.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://deadline.com/2014/06/intl-box-office-godzilla-thrashes-again-with-38m-weekend-led-by-china-how-to-train-your-dragon-2-fires-up-24-8m-more-788313/ | title = Final Int’l Box Office: ‘Godzilla’ Thrashes Again With $38.4M Weekend Led By China; ‘How To Train Your Dragon 2′ Fires Up $24.4M; ‘Fault’ On Fire In Brazil | author = Nancy Tartaglione | publisher = Deadline.com | date = June 16, 2014 | accessdate = December 9, 2014}}</ref>

==Hindi remake== {{Main article|Kizie Aur Manny}}
On August 6, 2014, India's [[Fox Star Studios]] announced its intention to remake the film. In March 2018, actor [[Sushant Singh Rajput]] was announced as the male lead in the official Hindi adaptation of the film. The film also marks the directorial debut of former casting director Mukesh Chhabra.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Fault In Our Stars remake: Sushant Singh Rajput, debutante Sanjana Sanghi in Mukesh Chhabra's directorial debut- Entertainment News, Firstpost|url=http://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/the-fault-in-our-stars-remake-sushant-singh-rajput-debutante-sanjana-sanghi-in-mukesh-chhabras-directorial-debut-4395745.html|website=Firstpost|accessdate= March 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='The Fault In Our Stars' remake: Sushant Singh Rajput to romance Sanjana Sanghi in Mukesh Chhabra's film|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/bollywood/report-the-fault-in-our-stars-remake-sushant-singh-rajput-to-romance-sanjana-sanghi-in-mukesh-chhabra-s-film-2595291|website=dna|accessdate=March 19, 2018|date=March 19, 2018}}</ref> The film, like many Bollywood films, will be a musical, and Oscar winner [[A.R. Rahman]] will compose its music.{{cn|date=August 2018}} Actress [[Sanjana Sanghi]] was announced as the female lead later that month.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sanjana Sanghi To Star Opposite Sushant Singh Rajput In 'The Fault In Our Stars' Remake|url=https://www.news18.com/news/movies/sanjana-sanghi-to-star-opposite-sushant-singh-rajput-in-the-fault-in-our-stars-remake-1693571.html|website=News18|accessdate=March 19, 2018}}</ref>

The '''World Crafts Council AISBL (WCC-AISBL)''' is a non-profit, non-governmental organization that was founded in 1964 to promote fellowship, foster economic development through income generating craft related activities, organize exchange programs, workshops, conferences, seminars, and exhibitions—and in general, to offer encouragement, help, and advice to the craftspersons of the world. The organization is now formally registered in Belgium as an international organization and ''AISBL'' is there the french shortcut for an ''international [[association without lucrative purpose]]''. The WCC is organised into five regions: Africa, Asia Pacific, Europe, Latin America, and North America. The organization is affiliated to [[UNESCO]].
The WCC was founded in 1964 by [[Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay|Kamaladevi Chattopadhay]] and [[Aileen Osborn Webb]] (who had founded the [[American Craft Council]] in 1943.)<ref>[http://craftvic.org.au/resources/craft-culture/2002/global-peace-through-craft-the-formation-of-the-world-crafts-council ''Global Peace Through Craft: The Formation of the World Crafts Council'', By Sandra Alfoldy], 2002</ref> The WCC (Europe) meets once a year and the 2011 meeting was held in [[Dublin, Ireland]].<ref>[http://culture360.org/event/dublin-world-crafts-council-europe-conference/ ''Dublin: World Crafts Council Europe conference'', by Judith Staines], 17 May 2011</ref>
The World Crafts Council meets every four years. In 2012, the General Assembly occurred in [[Chennai]] when [http://www.kaivalam.com/ Usha Krishna] was the President.<ref>[http://www.kaivalam.com ''Kaivalam''] Kaivalam Craft Summit</ref> After this General Assembly the Presidency will move from India to China. Mr. Wang Shan was the president, Ms. Jing Chen was the Secretary General. In 2014, WCC Golden Jubliee Celebration Summit was held in Dongyang, China, more than 2000 craftpeople from 63 countries participated. In 2016, the General Assembly occurred in [[Isfahan, Iran]]<ref>[http://isfwcc.ir/wcc18th/Introduction.aspx , ''The 18th General Assembly of the World Crafts Council Isfahan''], 2016</ref> from September 22 to 29.

'''Yongwoo Lee''' (born in [[Seoul]]) is an art historian, critic and curator.<ref>http://www.artinasia.kr/content/view/56/32/ Art in Asia Interview</ref>
== Biography == Yongwoo Lee is executive director of the Shanghai Himalayas Museum. He was the president of the IBA (International Biennial Association) from 2014 to 2017.<ref>http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/126006/international-biennial-association-s-4th-general-assembly/ International Biennial Association's 4th General Assembly</ref>
== Curatorial career == Yongwoo Lee is the founding director of the [[Gwangju Biennale]], established in 1995, and served as president of the Gwangju Biennale Foundation for six years (2008-2014). He is the founder and executive director of [[Shanghai Project]] since 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shanghai-project.org/about/structure/|title=Shanghai Project Structure|last=|first=|date=|website=www.shanghai-project.org/about/structure/|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Publications == His published books include: ''Information and Reality'' (Fruitmarket Gallery Edinburgh),<ref>https://www.amazon.com/gp/search?index=books&linkCode=qs&keywords=0947912274 ''Information and Reality''</ref> ''Nam June Paik'' (Samsung Publication),<ref>http://www.worldcat.org/title/nam-june-paik/oclc/84526910 ''Nam June Paik''</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/origins-of-video-art/oclc/43194073.|title=The origins of video art|work=worldcat.org}}</ref>

{{Japanese name|Kanze}} [[File:Zeami.png|thumb|A wooden statue of Zeami]] {{Nihongo|'''Zeami Motokiyo'''|世阿弥 元清}} (c. 1363 – c. 1443), also called {{Nihongo|'''Kanze Motokiyo'''|観世 元清}}, was a Japanese [[Aesthetics|aesthetician]], actor, and playwright. His father, [[Kan'ami]], introduced him to [[Noh]] theater performance at a young age, and found that he was a skilled actor. Kan'ami was also skilled in acting and formed a family theater ensemble. As it grew in popularity, Zeami had the opportunity to perform in front of the [[Ashikaga shogunate|Shōgun]], [[Ashikaga Yoshimitsu]]. The Shōgun was impressed by the young actor and began to compose a friendship with him. Zeami was introduced to Yoshimitsu's court and was provided with an education in classical literature and philosophy while continuing to act. In 1374, Zeami received patronage and made acting his career. After the death of his father in 1385, he led the family troupe, a role in which he found greater success.
Zeami mixed a variety of Classical and Modern themes in his writing, and made use of Japanese and Chinese traditions. He incorporated numerous themes of [[Zen]] Buddhism into his works and later commentators have debated the extent of his personal interest in Zen. The exact number of plays that he wrote is unknown, but is likely to be between 30 and 50. He wrote many treatises about Noh, discussing the philosophy of performance. These treatises are the oldest known works on the philosophy of drama in Japanese literature, but did not see popular circulation until the 20th-century.
After the death of Yoshimitsu, his successor [[Ashikaga Yoshimochi]] was less favorable to Zeami's drama. Zeami successfully sought out patronage from wealthy merchants and continued his career under their support. He became well-known and well-respected in Japanese society. [[Ashikaga Yoshinori]] became hostile toward Zeami after becoming Shōgun in 1429. Yoshinori held Zeami's nephew Onnami in high regard, and disagreed with Zeami's refusal to declare Onnami his successor as leader of his troupe. Possibly due to this disagreement, though a variety of competing theories have been advanced, Yoshinori sent Zeami into exile to [[Sado, Niigata|Sado Island]]. After Yoshinori's death in 1441, Zeami returned to mainland Japan, where he died in 1443.
==Early life== Zeami was born in 1363<ref name=h96p14/> in [[Nagoya]]<ref name=h96p15/> and was known as Kiyomota as a child.<ref name=h96p14>Hare 1996, p. 14</ref> His mother was the daughter of a priest and a Fief Lord.<ref name=h96p15>Hare 1996, p. 15</ref> His father Kanami led a theater troupe<ref name=h96p14/> which primarily performed in the [[Kyoto]] region,<ref name=h96p12>Hare 1996, p. 12</ref> before becoming popular in the late 1360s and early 1370s. As they became better-known, Kanami's troupe began to perform in Daijogi.<ref name=h96p16/> Zeami acted in the troupe and was considered attractive and highly skilled.<ref name=h96p18>Hare 1996, p. 18</ref>
Ebina no Naami, an adviser of the Shōgun Ashikaga Yoshimitsu, booked the troupe to perform for the Shōgun, who was then 17 years old.<ref name=h96p12/> The shōgun was very powerful politically and was a patron of the arts.<ref name=rxviii/> He was impressed by the troupe, and patronized Kanami. The troupe began to focus on the entertainment value of performance, rather than its religious significance. It had been a form of entertainment associated with the country, but with Yoshimitsu's support it became associated with the upper class.<ref name=h96p13>Hare 1996, p. 13</ref> The Shōgun was highly attracted to Zeami, which proved controversial among aristocrats because of Zeami's lower-class background.<ref name=h96p16>Hare 1996, p. 16</ref> Yoshimitsu regularly invited Kanami and Zeami to the court, and Zeami accompanied him to events.<ref name=w43>Wilson 2006, p. 43</ref> Due to his connection with the Shōgun, Zeami was provided with a classical education by court statesman and poet Nijo Yoshimoto.<ref name=h96p17>Hare 1996, p. 17</ref> Nijo was renowned for his skill as a [[Renga]] and taught Zeami about Literature, Poetry, and Philosophy. This type of education was very unusual for an actor: due to their lower-class backgrounds, actors received little education.<ref name=rxviii/>
==Career== Zeami received patronage in 1374, which was then an uncommon honor for an actor.<ref name=h96p17/> Patronage allowed him to become a vocational artist<ref name=h96p11>Hare 1996, p. 11</ref> and he began to lead the troupe after his father's death in 1385. The troupe became successful during his tenure as a leader.<ref name=h96p21>Hare 1996, p. 21</ref> While leading the troupe, he wrote the first Japanese treatises on pragmatic aesthetics.<ref name=h96p12/>
Zeami adhered to a [[Formalism (art)|formalist]] writing process: he began with a topic, determined the structure, and finished by writing the lyrics. The number of plays that he wrote is uncertain, but numbers at least 30. His intellectual interests were eclectic<ref name=h96p11/> and he was a proficient writer of Renga.<ref name=h96p19>Hare 1996, p. 19</ref> ''[[The Tale of the Heike]]'' was the source of several of his best known plays.<ref name=w153>Wilson 2006, p. 153</ref> He integrated Japanese and Chinese ancient poetry into his drama.<ref name=w18>Wilson 2006, p. 18</ref> Contemporary dramatists Doami and Zoami had a significant influence on him,<ref name=h96p30/> earning recognition in his treatises. He spoke particularly well of Zoami,<ref name=rxviii/> but his shift toward Yugen and away from Monomane may have been because of Doami's influence.<ref name=h96p31>Hare 1996, p. 31</ref> He mixed popular dance, drama, and music with classical poetics and thus broadened and popularized the classical tradition.<ref name=h96p12/> In his earlier work, he used Zen illustrations, creating new Zen words and using established Zen words out of context. Many of the themes he used are present in other schools of Buddhism.<ref name=h96p31/> Japan was dominated by a focus on Zen culture then, and he was registered at a Zen temple<ref name=h96p32/> and was a friend of a well-known Zen priest.<ref name=h96p31/> In 1422, he became a lay monk.<ref name=w45>Wilson 2006, p. 45</ref>
One of the most important performances of Zeami's career occurred in 1394. At that time, Ashikaga Yoshimitsu visited the [[Kasuga-taisha|Kasuga shrine]] in [[Nara Prefecture|Nara]] and Zeami performed during the visit.<ref name=h96p22>Hare 1996, p. 22</ref> It was a significant political event, so Zeami was likely a well known artist then. He gave two significant performances for the Shōgun in 1399,<ref name=h96p23>Hare 1996, p. 23</ref> one of which could have been attended by [[Emperor Go-Komatsu]].<ref name=h96p25>Hare 1996, p. 25</ref>
Zeami found Yoshimitsu to be a difficult patron,<ref name=h96p25/> and was rivaled by Inuo, a [[Sarugaku]] actor, for the favor of the Shōgun.<ref name=h96p26/> Though Yoshimitsu died in 1408,<ref name=h96p26>Hare 1996, p. 26</ref> and new Shōgun, Yoshimochi, was indifferent to Zeami<ref name=rxix>Rimer 1984, p. xix</ref> and preferred the [[dengaku]] work of Zoami,<ref name=rxviii/> Zeami's career remained strong<ref name=h96p28/> due to his connections with the urban commercial class. Due to his status as a well respected public figure, he had access to a number of patrons.<ref name=h96p28>Hare 1996, p. 28</ref> He eventually reached the stature of a celebrity<ref name=rxviii>Rimer 1984, p. xviii</ref> and wrote a significant amount between 1418 and 1428.<ref name=h96p28/>
==Plays== Authorship of noh plays is a complex issue and often a matter of debate. Many plays have been attributed to Zeami, and he was known to be involved in revising and transmitting many others. But some plays are decisively known to have been written by him. The following are universally attributed to Zeami:<ref name=Tyler92>Tyler 1992, plays introduction</ref>
* Akoya no Matsu, currently not in the noh repertoire * [[Atsumori (play)|Atsumori]] * Hanjo * [[Izutsu]], probably written in the late 1420s or early 1430s * Kinuta, probably written in the early 1430s * [[Matsukaze]], using a section by [[Kan'ami]] * Saigyo Zakura * [[Sekidera Komachi]] * Tadanori * [[Takasago (play)|Takasago]] * [[Yamanba (Noh play)|Yamamba]] * Yashima
==Treatises== Zeami produced 21 critical writings over a period of roughly four decades.<ref name=q1/> His treatises discuss the principles of Noh. He sought to inform his colleagues of the most important aspects of theater, discussing character acting, music, and physical movement.<ref name=rxvii>Rimer 1984, p. xvii</ref> They also discussed broader themes, such as how life should be lived.<ref name=w15>Wilson 2006, p. 15</ref> The treatises were intended for a small circle of his colleagues, since the troupes were hereditary and such information was traditionally passed down between generations. He desired to facilitate this process<ref name=rxix/> to ensure continued patronage for the troupe.<ref name=rxx/>
===Fūshikaden=== Zeami wrote several treatises on drama, the first of which was the {{Nihongo||風姿花伝|Fūshikaden|"The Transmission of the Flower Through (a Mastery of) the Forms", more loosely "Style and the Flower"}}, known colloquially as {{Nihongo||花伝書|Kadensho|"The Book of Transmission of the Flower"}}. It is the first known treatise on drama in Japan;<ref name=h96p23/> though similar treatises were written by Japanese Buddhist sects and poets, this is the Noh treatise. [[J. Thomas Rimer]] suggests that Zeami's education in Renga poetry provided him with the idea.<ref name=rxx>Rimer 1984, p. xx</ref> It notably includes a thorough analysis of [[jo-ha-kyū]], which Zeami viewed as a universal concept. His first treatise includes much of his father's views of Noh.<ref name=h96p23/>
===Kakyo=== The treatise ''Kakyo'' was written later and describes Zeami's personal views. Though ''Fushikaden'' discusses flowers at length, ''Kakyo'' deals with spiritual beauty and contains discourses on the voice of the actor and the actors' minds.<ref name=h96p30>Hare 1996, p. 30</ref> A possible interest in Zen has been credited with this shift by some scholars.<ref name=h96p31/> The change in his age between his first and last works also appears to have significantly affected his perspective.<ref name=h96p32/> He spent a significant amount of time writing ''Kakyo'' and gave the completed work to his son Motomasa,<ref name=h96p29>Hare 1996, p. 29</ref> Zeami's son Motoyoshi had previously transcribed Zeami's treatise ''Reflections on Art''.<ref name=rxix/>
==Decline== After Ashikaga Yoshinori became the Shōgun, he demonstrated a deeper disdain for Zeami than his predecessors had,<ref name=h96p32/> though the origins of his feelings are unknown. Speculation has centered on Zeami's association with Masashige<ref name=h96p32>Hare 1996, p. 32</ref> and the theory that Zeami was a restorationist.<ref name=h96p12/> In 1967, the Kanze-Fukudu genealogy was found and gave credence to the idea that politics contributed to Yoshinori's treatment of Zeami. The genealogy showed that a brother of Zeami's mother was a supporter of the southern court against the Ashikaga Shogunate.<ref name=h96p14/> Yoshinori is sometimes seen as eccentric, and it has been speculated that he punished Zeami because he did not enjoy his performances. (Yoshinori preferred colorful plays<ref name=h96p33>Hare 1996, p. 33</ref> that involved actor portraying demons; these types of plays were seldom found in Zeami's repertoire.)<ref name=h96p35>Hare 1996, p. 35</ref> Yoshinori, who enjoyed Monomane, preferred Onnami,<ref name=h96p33/> as his performances included demons.<ref name=h96p35/> Zeami had been close with his Onnami and they had performed together.<ref name=h96p35/> Zeami had been unsure whether any of his sons would be able to lead the troupe after his death, so he paid special attention to Onnami's development.<ref name=w46>Wilson 2006, p. 46</ref> Motomasa, however, began to lead the troupe in 1429.<ref name=w46/> That year, though Motomasa and Onnami each performed for Yoshinori during a 10-day festival<ref name=h96p345>Hare 1996, p. 34-35</ref> Yoshinori forbade Zeami to appear at the [[Sentō Imperial Palace]],<ref name=h96p32/> possibly due to his refusal to provide Onnami with his complete writings.<ref name=w46/> The next year, the music directorship of the Kiyotaki shrine was transferred from Motomasa to Onnami.<ref name=h96p32/> That year Zeami's son Motoyoshi retired from acting to serve as a Buddhist priest.<ref name=rxix/> That same year Motomasa died; it has been speculated that he was murdered.<ref name=h96p32/> Though he had lost political favor, Zeami continued to write prolifically.<ref name=h96p36/>
Onnami inherited the leadership of Zeami's Kanze school.<ref name=h96p35/> The appointment was made by the Shogunate, although the troupes were traditionally hereditary.<ref name=rxix/> Zeami initially opposed Onnami's leadership of the troupe, but he eventually acquiesced.<ref name=h96p35/> Zeami believed that his line had died with Motomasa, but Onnami felt that he continued the line.<ref name=h96p36/> Zeami gave his completed works to [[Konparu Zenchiku]], rather than to Onnami.<ref name=h96p36>Hare 1996, p. 36</ref>
==Sado Island== In 1434, Zeami was exiled to Sado Island.<ref name=h96p32/> He completed his last recorded work two years later, providing a detailed first-person account of his exile.<ref name=h96p37>Hare 1996, p. 37</ref> In the account he conveys a stoic attitude toward his misfortunes.<ref name=w47>Wilson 2006, p. 47</ref> Little is known about the end of his life, but it was traditionally believed that he was pardoned and return to the mainland before his death.<ref name=rxix/> Zeami died in 1443 and was buried in Yamato. His wife died a short time later.<ref name=h96p38>Hare 1996, p. 38</ref>
==Legacy== Zeami is known as the foremost writer of Noh and the artist who brought it to its classical epitome.<ref name=h96p12/> Scholars attribute roughly 50 plays to him, many of which have been translated into European languages. The contemporary versions of his plays are sometimes simplified. Some of his plays are no longer extant, and roughly 16 exist only in the form of rare manuscripts.<ref name=rxxvii>Rimer 1984, p. xxvii</ref>
There are few extant biographical documents of Zeami, the lack of solid information about his life has led to a significant amount of speculation.<ref name=h96p12/> Some common themes in the speculation are that Zeami could have been a spy, a Ji sect priest, or a Zen master.<ref name=h96p12/>
Zeami's treatises were not widely available after his death, only the upper-class warriors were able to gain access to them. In 1908, several of the treatises were discovered at a used-book store in Japan. They gained wider circulation after this discovery but a complete set was not published until 1940.<ref name=w49>Wilson 2006, p. 49</ref> Zeami's plays have been continually performed in Japan since they were first written.<ref name=q1>Quinn 2005, p. 1</ref>
